content.description:
The obvious left-facing corner on the lower tier, the easier and better approach pitch option to the midway ledge. Likely still a bit dirty.

Climb the corner with liebacking, face climbing, and stemming, finishing with a steep step right to gain the ledge.
content.protection: Gear to #3 C4. A #4 might be useful but my memory is vague.
content.location: The trail drops you right at the base.

content.description:
In it's current state, it's as appealing as it's name. This was a ground-up foray to gain the midway ledge and the harder and dirtier approach pitch. There are bits of good climbing buried under the dirt, I promise. With significant cleaning (which we didn't do, sorry) or even a bolted variation to the left, this could be good. The rock and pro is good, at least.

Start 15 feet to the right of the Drawbridge in a shallow left facing corner. Climb this, stepping onto a slab below two hand crack bulges when the corner ends. These provide the crux. An easier hand crack takes you to another ledge, where you can either climb straight up with minimal pro, or, veer hard left along a ramp before pulling jugs onto the midway ledge. Bolted anchor.
content.protection: Gear to #3 C4, doubles in hand size.
content.location: 15 feet further right of where the trail leads you. Basically the center of the lower tier.

content.description:
Steep for the grade (especially in Leavenworth) but loaded with jugs.

The easier moves before the first bolt can be protected by finger size gear. Hand traverse the juggy, bolt-protected rail with good feet and fun exposure to a mantle (gear) at the lip. Short but fun, safe and well-protected for someone breaking into the grade.

From the bolted anchor, you can lower back to the ledge or rap to the ground with a 70m rope.
content.protection: 2 bolts and a couple cams. The finish is protected with a hands or wide hands sized piece. Two bolt anchor at top.
content.location: The leftmost route off the midway ledge. There's a small tree growing out of the start of the hand traverse, treat it kindly.

content.description:
The swooping, rightward traverse off the midway ledge. More delicate than powerful, but it takes a little of both.

Walk right from the ledge's bolted anchor, step up to clip the first bolt, and finger traverse right with increasing difficulty. Just as it starts getting desperate, a reach gains the juggy lip.

The business of this climb is well protected by four bolts, and should be a friendly lead for someone at their limit. Trad gear is needed only as a directional for the follower after pulling the lip, where a .75 and/or 1 C4 (green/red Totems would be even better) can be placed in a horizontal before shuffling left to the bolted anchor. Don't forgo the gear, your follower and rope will hate you.

From the bolted anchor, it's a 35m free-hanging rap to the ground. You can also traverse a little further left, and rap back to the midway ledge from the Bartizan anchor.
content.protection: Four bolts + green or red C4 or equivalent
content.location: The rightmost route on the upper tier, midway ledge. Look for the four bolts.
